abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Grassroots Development
            Initiatives Project in Togo are as follows: overall outcome
            of the project was rated satisfactory, and the performance
            of the Bank and the Borrower were rated satisfactory. Some
            of the lessons learned from the project are: 1) the building
            of a relationship between Government and non government
            organizations (NGOs) is a time-consuming exercise,
            particularly if the parties are not obviously willing to
            work together as partners from the beginning; 2) when
            intermediaries are key actors in a project, it is important
            to have appropriate eligibility criteria and pre selection
            process to ensure that those intermediaries have the
            necessary qualifications and experience to do the work. The
            pre selection of NGOs must determine whether they have the
            technical competence and financial capacity to meet their
            obligations for carrying out sub-projects; and 3)
            well-designed training programs for NGOs, as well as for
            associations or groups of beneficiaries, should be an
            integral part of the operation and should be a priority. The
            existence of a clear legal framework defining the
            responsibilities of NGOs and other stakeholders would also help.
